Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the meeting reminder flashing insistently. My team was gathering in ten minutes, and I knew this session was crucial—project updates, new assignments, things I couldn’t afford to miss. But just as I was about to head out, my younger brother called from the backyard. He was strapping on his helmet, grinning, and pointing at the steep, cracked ramp he’d been eyeing for weeks. “Watch this, I’m finally going to nail it!” he shouted. My heart pounded. As his sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But as a colleague, I was expected to be present, engaged, and reliable. I could already imagine my manager’s disappointment if I skipped the meeting, and my brother’s crushed look if I left him alone. Torn between the urgent pull of family and the pressing demands of work, I stood frozen, phone in one hand, helmet in the other, wrestling with which part of me should take the lead.
